content.question: A student is performing an experiment in which protons with a horizontal speed of <math alttext="10 to the power 6, meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>m</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> enter a region with a uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="10 to the power negative 2, Tesla" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>T</mi></mstyle></mrow></math>, as shown above. The student observes the deflection of the protons by the magnetic field, and in analyzing the data ignores the effects of gravity on the protons. Does the student need to revise the analysis? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because neglecting the effect of gravity will introduce large errors in the analysis.
Yes, because all forces must always be included in an experimental analysis.
No, because the magnetic force and the gravitational force on the protons are both directed downward.
No, because the force of gravity on the protons is negligible compared to the magnetic force.

content.answer: No, because the force of gravity on the protons is negligible compared to the magnetic force.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
